description:
Greek bank deposits have fallen to their lowest level of more than ten years even as another debt deadline looms. According to the European Central Bank deposits in April stood at just shy of €140 billion, that's nearly 4% down on March. The Greek government, the EU and the IMF have been arguing for four months now over reforms that must be implemented before the latest 7-billion-euro chunk of bailout money is released. Before that can happen a lot of money's got to go the other way - Greece has to pay off one and a half billion euros to the IMF by the 5th of June, that's just a week off. And discussion of a possible Greek exit from the eurozone heated up again on Thursday when the IMF head Christine Lagarde was quoted in the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung as saying "It was a possibility." The BBC's Theopi Skarlatos asks how much more uncertainty Greeks can take.

At the General Hospital of Nikaia in Athens only six operating theatres are in action. There are 11 that could be. But due to austerity cuts imposed during the crisis, they don't have the staff available. Neurosurgeon Doctor Papanicolaou says the healthcare system is at breaking point.

We have problems in everyday things, the food for the patients, everyday things as clinic paper, as soap, our all things like that. There are periods for one, two or three months that there is a lack of these things.
